Authors:
Isabel Cruz-Lachica, Isidro Marquez-Zequera, Raul
Allende-Molar, Josefa Adriana Sanudo-Barajas, Josefina Leon-Felix, Nancy
Ley-Lopez, Raymundo Saul Garcia-Estrada
Title:
Diversity of Mucoralean Fungi in Soils of Papaya (Carica
papaya L.) Producing Regions in Mexico
Abstract:
Mexico is the fifth largest producer of papaya worldwide
and has recently reported problems with mucoralean fungi in this crop.
These fungi are considered saprophytes in the soil and are ubiquitous in
nature. In this work, they were isolated from soil in regions of
intensive papaya cultivation in Mexico. Collections were made in the
states of Colima, Oaxaca and Veracruz in April 2016. Morphological and
molecular characterization (28S ribosomal region) of 25 representative
strains was carried out. Phylogenetic analysis of the sequences
confirmed the presence of the species Choanephora cucurbitarum,
Gilbertella persicaria, Mucor ellipsoideus, M. circinelloides, M.
hiemalis, Rhizopus homothallicus, R. microsporus, R. stolonifer, R.
oryzae, R. schipperae, Lichteimia ramosa, Gongronella butleri,
Cunninghamella polymorpha and C. blakesleeana, belonging to the families
Choanephoraceae, Mucoraceae, Rhizopodaceae, Lichteimiaceae and
Cunninghamellaceae, which are considered to have biotechnological,
agricultural and medical importance. Gilbertella persicaria, Rhizopus
oryzae, R. stolonifer, Mucor circinelloides and M. hiemalis, which cause
soft rot in papaya fruits, were found in the soil and can be considered
as a constant source of contamination that affects healthy fruits.
